info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 1, game 6.

double_jeopardy_round: WE MAKE MONEY THE OLD-FASHIONED WAY

(1, 1).clue: June 7: Norway dissolves the union that had existed since 1814 with this country

(2, 1).clue: "Ron Guidry is not very big, maybe 140 pounds, but he has an arm like" this king of beasts

(3, 1).clue: In a classic children's story, the Big Bad Wolf ends up in a pot of boiling water in this trio's kitchen

(5, 1).clue: Some believe that the eradication of so many cats in the 14th century may have led to spread of this scourge

(6, 1).clue: Monty Python famously sang, "I'm" one of these "and I'm okay, I sleep all night and I work all day"

(1, 2).clue: July 16: This American commander sets off on his second expedition to the North Pole

(2, 2).clue: "Today is Father's Day, so everyone out there, Happy" this, a 1968 Beatles tune

(3, 2).clue: Beginning an amazing run of about 200 comedy two-reelers, this trio made "Woman Haters" in 1934

(5, 2).clue: Bred in Scotland in the 1960s, the Scottish fold has these folded forward

(6, 2).clue: A telecom company, or a word meaning shining or clear

(1, 3).clue: January 26:This largest rough gem-quality diamond ever found is unearthed in South Africa

(2, 3).clue: "The first pitch to Tucker Ashford is grounded into left field. No, wait a minute. It's" this 2-word term, "low & outside"

(3, 3).clue: The alliance of Britain, France & Russia during World War I

(5, 3).clue: The tail status determines the 4 varieties of this cat: Rumpy, Rumpy Riser, Stumpy & Longy

(6, 3).clue: A substance, such as oil or grease, for lessening friction in the working parts of a mechanism

(1, 4).clue: November 28:Arthur Griffith forms this nationalist political party in Dublin

(2, 4).clue: "Winfield goes back... He hits his head on the wall & it rolls off!  It's rolling" to here, the usual position of Robbie Alomar

(3, 4).clue: Sibling celebrity trios includethese silent-film sisters: Norma, Constance & Natalie

(5, 4).clue: The largest domestic cat, it originated in New England & resembles a raccoon

(6, 4).clue: As an adjective, it means opulent; as slang, it means a drunkard

(1, 5).clue: June 13:Prime Minister Delyannis of this Mediterranean country is assassinated

(2, 5).clue: "If Don Mattingly isn't the American League MVP, something isn't kosher in" this Asian country

(3, 5).clue: Havana's striking landmark the El Morro Castle & Fort is dedicated to this holiday trio, the patrons of its chapel

(5, 5).clue: A splinter group of Ragdoll cat breeders called their breed this, because it descended from street urchin cats

(1, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from a lab.)  I'm at a University of Pittsburgh campus building named for this doctor--it's where he did the research that led to the polio vaccine

(3, 1).clue: Chapter 9 of this 1851 Hawthorne novel is titled "Clifford and Phoebe"
(3, 1).correct response: The House of the Seven Gables (House of Seven Gables accepted)

(4, 1).clue: The hero of Vicksburg is on it

(5, 1).clue: This co., owner of NBC Universal, Inc., showed its "imagination at work" in 2003 with revenues of $134.2 billion

(6, 1).clue: In 2003 Jason Schmidt led the NL in this stat with 2.34
(6, 1).correct response: earned run average (earned runs average accepted)

(3, 2).clue: This 1961 title became a term for illogical bureaucratic rule

(4, 2).clue: It features the author of "Notes on the State of Virginia"

(6, 2).clue: The 4 words that follow the classic "Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses..."

(4, 3).clue: As president, the man on this bill crushed the Whiskey Rebellion

(4, 4).clue: It shows a man who wrote, "I... confess plainly that events have controlled me"
